title: [Proposal] Matchmaking Improvements and Labels
body:
The time has come for Riot to tackle community issues and turn league of legends into the true MOBA dream. I am a frequent player of League of Legends who is determined to try to improve this community. However, with my recent experiences in league of legends consisting of toxicity and the occasional intentional feeder, it is obvious action must be performed. Today I will be proposing a series of features that will in theory inspire players to be more positive, and give vital punishments to disincentivize whatever riot deems as improper behavior. 

#[The Plan]

(Note, this is a long term solution, and probably won't have much influence when first introduced.)

#PART 1: Matchmaking and Labels

My theory revolves around a system of visible and invisible labels, as well as mods and similar qualified community members working together to identify truly bad members of the community. The first part of this plan, the labels, will be used to more clearly assist in overall tribunal activity. This would include having players labeled as toxic or as feeders (more on how these labels would be dispensed in the mods/community part of the plan). This can be applied to any aspect of the report system, from people who frequently leave, to people who are just generally rude or disrespectful to teammates and other members of the community. Additionally, the same could be done for positive community influences, similar to the honor system. My personal belief is that negative labels will be kept inaccessible to regular members of the community, while positive influences will be proudly displayed to other people. 

http://i.imgur.com/ASj7ZcT.jpg

Another way to promote the benefits of positive players is to group positive players when in matchmaking. This can also be applied to making games full of people labeled as prone to toxicity. This feature will incentivize being positive, which will effectively lead to a more positive community. Positive members of the community will be rewarded by being grouped with other positive people, overall improving the League of Legends experience. 

http://i.imgur.com/8BupMhl.png

Tiers of negativity and positivity can also be created in order to avoid the problem of more neutral players being matched with serious offenders. A simple way to complete this is to have "+" signs as a way to ranking positive tiers. These plus signs can be displayed next to usernames in loading screens, chats, as well as on profiles.

http://i.imgur.com/Q6z8Xi9.jpg

http://i.imgur.com/vdj1owd.png 

Tribunal wise, people labeled as prone to leaving or toxic can be taken better care of by experiencing their own problem first hand (getting a taste of their own medicine, so to speak). This can be done with a series of "-" signs labeling the player, however, in the case of a negative attitude player, their negative tiers should only be available to mods, in order to avoid any conflicts pertaining to outright saying "this guy is toxic" to the whole community.

http://i.imgur.com/H3XiYUP.png

 After this feature is implemented, "+"s will be acquired possibly by assisting a mod who has joined a game (more on that later), or just having "+"s distributed based on a players in game honor, based on frequency of their honor, of course. Adding on to that, at the end of the game, members of both team could nominate a person from the game to get a "+" (most likely a ranked game, due to the more serious nature of the queue), in which after this a mod will review the game's chat logs and even possibly spectate a game from the nominee. If the nominee deserves to receive a "+" then bam, we have an accurate assessment of good people in the community. The opposite of this should also be possible, with players able to nominate multiple players for a "-" tier. Mods can easily see the chat logs of these players and most likely assign them with their well deserved label. In order to avoid a literal ELO hell, players vote as toxic trapped with other toxic players will be able to apply for a mod to reset their label. In this case, a mod would view the applicant's games and chat logs and deem them worthy or unworthy of leaving ELO hell. This system is efficient because it doesn't give complete control to either side. The only way this system can be corrupted would be with the inclusion of corrupt mods who don't attempt to uphold league's rules. Part 2 of the proposal covers my theoretical mod system. 

#PART 2: Mods and Community Members. 

This portion of my proposal is dedicated to a possible mod and player system to label the toxic members of the community. The first part of this revolves around having a process to recruit frequent and beyond outgoing members of the community as mods. These mods will have authority to join games and settle problems between players first hand. Mods will have full chat logs of each team, as well as the ability to deal with minor problems such as chat restrictions. Additionally, these mods can flat out end games in drastic enough situations. My proposed process of this will be mods determining the full extent of a games situation. The mod will then give a ban of various sizes to the violator(s). This will be followed by a loss prevention to the team with the unfortunate fate of dealing with the violator(s) and a win will be given to the enemy team due to the wrong place, wrong time nature of the encounter. The process of becoming a mod would be more up to Riot themselves to design, as I am only trying to propose a base for an improved system. This can theoretically be done various ways, one of which being an application system, or a promotion system based on number of "+"s. Additionally, a new voting system could be created where everyone within a game could request a mod (example shown below).  In this way mods will be able to effectively label wrong doers amongst the community, while also giving normal members of the community more power to influence the community in a positive manner. This voting system would have to revolve around the amount of "+" (described in part one), with people possessing more "+" positive tiers having more influence in the vote.

http://i.imgur.com/Fao7DAK.png

 With a staff of mods and a method of showing positive League members, neutral players will no longer have to become toxic to combat the insults of other community members.

(Note, an abundant staff of mods is needed for this plan, in which I'm sure the community would be more than happy to help riot improve the community. After all, the community is how we are represented, and no one wants to be represented as toxic.)

Conclusion: 
This proposal has been created as a way to both solve the problems inherit in the League of Legends matchmaking system, as well as in their reporting and honor system. This plan incentivizes being a good sport and supporting others, rather than forcing it on unwilling people. People who are just generally toxic will be stuck with their own kind, giving a new meaning to ELO hell. In this environment these players will learn to become less toxic and more supportive in order to avoid their own kind as teammates.

* This is being sent to various League of Legends YouTubers and other influential community members in order to determine the viability of this system as well as improve it. All YouTubers involved in recommendation and improvements will be credited below

SkyWilliams- No Response Yet
Gnarsies- No Response Yet
More to add (Please recommend) :


I inquire that everyone viewing this post adds on to the idea, and provides their thoughts on the proposal. I intend to make this post a nest for people to list complaints and suggestions that are otherwise ignored by the community and riot. 

##The community should be rewarded for positivity, rather than punished for negativity. Focusing on the positives is the only way to cause negative aspects to change.

I'm all for some of your suggestions especially the "vote in a moderator", the only thing I have gripes with is that relegating players to a prison like environment won't make them better people, the US incarceration institute is as much evidence you need to understand that depravity does not change people for the better. If you look at Scandinavia though, rehabilitation proves to be more promising to get people to drop bad habits and I think Lyte is pretty aware of this, but as far as implementation goes, I can't say. 

It's important that toxic players are separated from (the most) flammable environments, so taking them out of ranked is a start, but moving into rehab do they interact with other players? Do they play along side bots that spam tips in blue text? Who knows :)

Like I said in other comments, the system will have to be refined based on how it runs at first. My belief is that a toxic player will stop being toxic in order to avoid other toxic players, but it would be impossible to truly know until actually tested. The main purpose of a system like this, however, would be to award outgoing members of the community by queuing them with other outgoing members. The real dream is for a person good enough for plat to get from bronze to plat without any feeders, afks, or overall toxic environments. The shifting of the matchmaking system would allow skilled players who are helpful towards their teammates and opponents to flourish in the ranked system. And let's be honest, if someone is toxic enough to be trapped in a negative loop, they probably do not deserve to play with quality teammates.

The problem isn't toxic players not being unable to reform, like prisoners' island somehow makes getting back impossible, but rather the question of the burden of reentry. For instance, if you have 3-4 players raging at you, threatening to afk, going afk, it becomes more difficult to be positive. Personally I think the only way I'd remain level headed is to just mute all and never speak. This creates the issue of whether or not just not speaking is of value. It doesn't constitute positive behavior really and doesn't model reform as much as it does restraint.

Maybe I'm too prone to negative behavior, but I would bet that given the work I've done regarding my anger I probably am more aware of and resistant to reactivate impulses than many lol players who are not toxic. So if a neutral player would have difficulty not being negative and might only be able to not interact with the people in order to avoid negative behavior, is it reasonable to expect someone who has a history of negativity to be able to practice/learn how to be positive in this environment? If you can't get out by being silent, would the average lol player be able to get out (because if a neutral player put in the toxic prisoners' island is unable to get out it is an unreasonable burden to expect toxic players to reform there)? If you can get out by being silent and not reforming, won't it just be a cycle of "be quiet, get out, rage at teammates, get put in, be quiet, get out, ad infinitum?"

Personally I like the idea of mods to review negative behavior/frequently reported accounts. Yeah the auto system exists but wasn't that up before Forgiven was banned and he as reported in a ton of games before anything happened. Also more concrete incentives for being positive, such as being in the same que, but maybe the more positive behavior (not good play or skill, but being kind) points someone has the higher (by a small %) chance they get for 1st pick, 2nd pick, etc. Then for positive behavior you get better pick order average over a large enough games played sample. However, w/ riot saying they wan to institute TB draft for ranked next season  that would be redundant so I'm not sure what would be a good incentive.

Putting people with other toxic people isn't healthy. It just punishes the toxic people even harder by putting them together with people who will provoke them. You should probably keep the pool mixed.
Bring back the original tribunal.

If you label all the good people or the (not toxic and trolls). Isn't it the same as labeling the trolls. And if you put the non-trolls and toxic into the same games by default you would be putting the toxic and trolls into prisoners island. Both of these strategies have been proven ineffective in social reform.

The point of making this prison like structure is to be a temporary state for toxic players. Toxic players experiencing their own problems can apply for a reset in their tier, in which a mod will review them and see if they are willing to be a kind community member. The point of this isn't necessarily to satisfy uncooperative community members, but to save the positive members of the community from the struggle of feeders, toxic people, and everything inbetween. Thank you so much for the feedback though!!!
Additionally, labeling positive players is an incentive to make players positive, with their own fancy label that they can brag to the toxic players about.

From the look of the comments, I don't need to explain to you why prisoners' island is a bad idea that will never be implemented. It's been explained. 

Let's talk about toxicity in general and community mods.

"Toxic" is a word Dr. Lyte invented, meaning any negative behavior onto a victim that causes said victim to then spread negative behavior onto others, like a spreading poison. It is a word that describes an action that causes a specific reaction. When you report someone, any multitude of things could be causing that report. I've seen time and time again where a team will latch on to the failures of one person, for absolutely no reason, and blame the entire game's "inevitable" loss on that player. It's only over many games of being consistently reported can you see a possible cause and effect. That is why we have the report system we have today. 

Calling in an individual community mod completely undermines that whole logic. It makes a potentially innocent person subject to the decision of one random stranger. 

 Whose fault is it when:

* Draven goes 0/7
* Karma says he's bad and never last hits
* Draven tells her to shut the fuck up and peel better

I'm sure you have your own answer to that question, but the fact is that some people will blame both, some only one, some wouldn't even call it negative behavior.
 You said that, "The only way this system can be corrupted would be with the inclusion of **corrupt mods**", but the fact is that **toxic behavior** has too many interpretations for even the most good-intentioned community member to **accurately** judge upon. Even with your plus/minus thing (that in most likelihood could just as well turn a mod away from the truth as towards it), any punishment given off of that one game would likely be unrepresentative of what either deserves. 

Furthermore, let's assume Karma's team calls a mod in on Draven, and the mod does nothing. Karma still thinks Draven is bad and will still be angry with him, and Draven will be even more upset that he was persecuted by his whole team. In a lot of cases, calling in a mod would just be avoiding the problem of getting players to actually use the mute button and act maturely.

**tl;dr: A single mod can't determine whether someone is toxic for punishments, and sometimes that won't even fix the problem in the immediate term. I fail to see how community mods would be a significant improvement from our current system.**

>no one wants to be represented as toxic

As a side note, I take resentment to that. If nothing else, I am honest about what I believe, and I persistently share those ideas regardless of how they make me look. That is what being very toxic means to me. I do not attempt to be popular, I just want to be true to myself and what I think. Would it be better to not share some of my more critical thoughts? Probably, but that's not who I want to be.  You were warned when you read my name.

Splitting people based on toxicity will do nothing but increase queue times. Especially for people on the really high and really low end of the spectrum. 

And giving a loss forgiven for having a toxic player on the team would be a nightmare. They'd never have enough people to get to every game with a toxic player, and if someone played a game with someone they thought was toxic and didn't get the loss forgiven, they'd freak out and get mad and probably get more toxic because 'the other guy got away with it, so it doesn't matter what you say.'

Well, it doesn't necessarily need to increase the queue times. It would be a shift of current players. Queue time would only increase if number of people decreased. As shown in the picture, teammates grouped together aren't necessarily of the same label rank. It just means that the majority of teammates would have above average positivity level or negativity level. Additionally, the vote to call in a mod would be influenced more by members of the community proven to have integrity, the plus system. Players with negatives will have less influnce in the vote. This can be done with a value system, such as so and so amount of influence being needed. This is meant to be a large scale thing with many, many mods able to volunteer.

If positive players only ever get matched with positive players, queue times will go up because now there's an additional thing to check when matchmaker is attempting to matchmake (MMR, experience, etc.) It would reduce queue times because the number of people that are allowed to queue with you is reduced.

A positive player might call for a vote. That vote might bring in a mod. That mod might not think it's worth a loss forgiven (the toxic player is just kind of annoying instead of actively detrimental.) That positive player feels like they wasted time, and now consider 'kind of annoying' acceptable.

And why would I want to volunteer to be a mod? I'm willing to take some time and do Tribunal, because that doesn't take long and I can do it at my leisure. But if I wanted to be a mod, I'd have to be on call all the time between when I click 'I wish to be a mod now' and 'I do not wish to be a mod now.'  Meaning that is a fair portion of my day in which I can't do anything that might take up time, and I don't even get to play the game that I am trying to improve.

So this is about you not wanting to be a mod, not that there is a flaw in the system. Personally, I would love to be a mod, helping people in ranked to not be trolled and other problems.
The queue will only increase in time if they use the most basic system to calculate queues. It would be as difficult as changing queues to put bronzes against bronzes, which it of course already does. It would add a minuscule amount of strain on the queue length. As for amount of people, well, everyone is going to be either positive, negative or neutral. It would just make the queue take these in consideration when matchmaking. It wouldn't be restricted, it would be aimed towards the goal of making positive and negative teams.
